lessons.title: What is HTML?
lessons.content: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language used to structure content on the web. It defines elements like headings, paragraphs, images, and links. HTML forms the backbone of every website and works alongside CSS and JavaScript.

examples.code:
Hello World!

This is my first webpage.
examples.description: A simple HTML document structure

quiz.question: What does HTML stand for?
quiz.hint: It's the main web page structure language
quiz.explanation: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language, used to define the structure of web pages.

lessons.challenge: Create your first HTML file and display 'Welcome to My Website' using <h1>.
tips: HTML is not a programming language — it's a markup language.
Always include <!DOCTYPE html> at the top.

Tags define elements like

,

, etc.
HTML is case-insensitive but lowercase is standard.

lessons.title: HTML Document Structure
lessons.content: An HTML document has a specific structure including doctype, html, head, and body tags. Understanding this is key to writing valid pages.

examples.code:
Heading

Body content goes here.
examples.description: Basic HTML page layout

quiz.question: Which tag defines the document’s metadata?
quiz.hint: Contains meta information and title
quiz.explanation: The <head> section includes metadata, styles, and the document title.

lessons.challenge: Build an HTML skeleton with a title and one paragraph inside the body.
tips: Always include <head> and <body> sections.
Use <meta> tags for SEO and responsiveness.
The <title> tag defines the browser tab name.

lessons.title: HTML Tags and Elements
lessons.content: Tags are the building blocks of HTML. Elements are made of an opening tag, content, and closing tag.

examples.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is a heading
examples.description: Example of tags and elements

quiz.question: What is the difference between a tag and an element?
options: A tag wraps content; an element includes tags and content
Tag is content, element is code
quiz.answer: A tag wraps content; an element includes tags and content
quiz.hint: Think of open + content + close
quiz.explanation: An element includes the opening tag, content, and closing tag together.

lessons.challenge: Create one paragraph, one heading, and one bold text element.
tips: Every element has a start and end tag.

Some elements are self-closing (e.g., ,
).
Indent your HTML for readability.

lessons.title: Headings and Paragraphs
lessons.content:
Headings are defined from

to

. Paragraphs are written using

. Use headings hierarchically for SEO and readability.

examples.code:
Main Title

Subtitle

This is a paragraph of text explaining the topic.
examples.description: Using headings and paragraphs

quiz.question: Which heading tag is the largest?
quiz.hint: The first heading is the most important
quiz.explanation: The <h1> tag represents the top-level heading.

lessons.challenge: Write a small article with title, subtitle, and 3 paragraphs.
tips: Use only one <h1> per page.
Use headings in order for structure.
Avoid skipping heading levels.

lessons.title: Comments and Whitespace
lessons.content: Comments help explain code and are ignored by browsers. Whitespace helps make code readable.

examples.code: This text will be visible.
examples.description: Adding comments in HTML

quiz.question: What syntax is used for HTML comments?
quiz.hint: It starts with <! and ends with -->
quiz.explanation: HTML comments are written using <!-- comment --> syntax.

lessons.challenge: Add comments describing sections of your page.
tips: Use comments to clarify code.
Avoid unnecessary comments for simple lines.
Whitespace doesn't affect layout.

lessons.title: Bold, Italic, and Underline
lessons.content: Use <b> or <strong> for bold, <i> or <em> for italics, and <u> for underline. <strong> and <em> convey semantic importance.

examples.description: Formatting text using inline elements

quiz.question: Which tag conveys importance semantically?
quiz.hint: Used for accessibility and SEO
quiz.explanation: The <strong> tag indicates strong importance, useful for screen readers.

lessons.challenge: Write a paragraph with bold, italic, and underlined keywords.
tips: Prefer <strong> and <em> for accessibility.
Avoid using <u> for emphasis unless necessary.
Keep formatting consistent.

lessons.title: HTML Lists
lessons.content: Lists help organize items. Ordered lists use <ol>, unordered use <ul>, and each item is inside <li>.

examples.description: Unordered and ordered lists

quiz.question: Which tag defines a list item?
quiz.hint: Each item is wrapped in it
quiz.explanation: <li> defines a single list item.

lessons.challenge: Create a shopping list and a step-by-step cooking guide.
tips: Use <ul> for unordered items.
Use <ol> when order matters.
Nest lists for subcategories.

lessons.title: Links and Anchors
lessons.content: Links use the <a> tag with an href attribute. They can link to other pages, sections, or external sites.

examples.description: Basic and internal links

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the link destination?
quiz.hint: Hyperlink reference
quiz.explanation: The href attribute specifies the destination URL of a link.

lessons.challenge: Add navigation links to 3 pages in your website.
tips: Always use meaningful link text.
Use target='_blank' for new tabs.
Avoid 'click here'; describe the destination.

lessons.title: Images and Alt Text
lessons.content: Images are added with the tag using src and alt attributes. Alt text improves accessibility and SEO.

examples.description: Adding an image with alt text

quiz.question: What does the alt attribute provide?
quiz.hint: Displayed if image fails to load
quiz.explanation: Alt text describes an image for accessibility and appears when the image can’t load.

lessons.challenge: Add 3 images with descriptive alt text.
tips: Always include alt text for accessibility.
Optimize image sizes for performance.
Use descriptive filenames.

lessons.title: HTML Line Breaks and Horizontal Rules
lessons.content:
Use
for line breaks and
for thematic breaks or section separators.

examples.description: Using line and section breaks

quiz.question: Which tag creates a single line break?
quiz.hint: Self-closing tag
quiz.explanation: inserts a single line break.

lessons.challenge:
Create a poem layout using
and separate stanzas using
.
tips:
Use
sparingly — use paragraphs instead when possible.
Use <hr> to visually separate sections.
Both are self-closing tags.

lessons.title: Ordered and Unordered Lists
lessons.content: HTML provides two main types of lists: ordered lists (<ol>) and unordered lists (<ul>). Ordered lists are numbered automatically, while unordered lists use bullets. Each list item is wrapped in the <li> tag.

examples.description: Example of ordered and unordered lists

quiz.question: Which tag defines a list item in HTML?
quiz.hint: Each item must be wrapped inside this tag.
quiz.explanation: The <li> tag defines an individual list item within <ul> or <ol>.

lessons.challenge: Create a recipe list using <ol> for steps and <ul> for ingredients.
tips: Use <ul> for unordered items.
Use <ol> when order matters.
Nest lists for subcategories.

lessons.title: Definition Lists
lessons.content: Definition lists are used to display name/value pairs using <dl>, <dt>, and <dd> tags. <dt> defines the term, and <dd> describes it.

examples.description: Creating a definition list

quiz.question: Which tag defines a description in a definition list?
quiz.hint: It's used to define the description or detail part.
quiz.explanation: In a definition list, <dd> provides the description of the term defined by <dt>.

lessons.challenge: Create a glossary using <dl>, <dt>, and <dd> for five web-related terms.
tips: Use <dt> for the term and <dd> for its meaning.
Avoid using definition lists for layout purposes.
Definition lists are great for glossaries or FAQs.

lessons.title: Creating Basic Hyperlinks
lessons.content: Links are created using the <a> tag and the href attribute. They allow users to navigate between pages or to external websites.

examples.description: A basic hyperlink

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the destination of a link?
quiz.hint: Stands for Hyperlink Reference.
quiz.explanation: The href attribute defines the URL that the link will navigate to.

lessons.challenge: Create a navigation list with links to Home, About, and Contact pages.
tips: Use descriptive text for links.
Always include http or https for external URLs.
Avoid using 'click here' — describe the destination.

lessons.title: Anchor Links and Navigation
lessons.content: Anchor links connect to specific sections of the same page using the id attribute. They make long pages easier to navigate.

examples.description: Creating internal page anchors

quiz.question: What attribute is used to target a specific section for an anchor link?
quiz.hint: You reference it with a # symbol in the href.
quiz.explanation: Anchor links work by matching the href='#id' to an element’s id.

lessons.challenge: Add anchor links to jump between three sections of your webpage.
tips: Use anchor links for long content pages.
Keep section IDs simple and descriptive.
Ensure IDs are unique within the page.

lessons.title: Opening Links and Link Attributes
lessons.content: The target attribute controls how links open. Use target='_blank' to open in a new tab. The rel attribute improves security when linking externally.

examples.code: Open in New Tab
examples.description: Opening a link in a new tab

quiz.question: Which target value opens a link in a new tab?
quiz.hint: Think of a blank new tab.
quiz.explanation: The target='_blank' attribute opens the link in a new browser tab or window.

lessons.challenge: Create a set of social media links that open in new tabs safely using rel='noopener noreferrer'.
tips: Use target='_blank' with rel='noopener noreferrer' for security.
Use absolute URLs for external links.
Avoid opening too many links in new tabs — it can confuse users.

lessons.title: Inserting Images
lessons.content: The tag is used to embed images. It requires the src attribute for the image source and alt for alternative text.

examples.description: Basic image tag example

quiz.question: Which attribute defines the image file location?
quiz.hint: It stands for 'source'.
quiz.explanation: The src attribute specifies the path or URL to the image file.

lessons.challenge: Add three images with meaningful alt text to your webpage.
tips: Always include alt text for accessibility.
Use proper file formats like .jpg or .png.
Optimize image size for faster loading.

lessons.title: Responsive Images and Picture Element
lessons.content: Responsive images adjust to different screen sizes. Use the <picture> tag with <source> and srcset attributes for flexibility.

examples.description: Using the picture element for responsive images

quiz.question: Which tag allows multiple image sources for responsiveness?
quiz.hint: It’s used to wrap multiple sources.
quiz.explanation: The <picture> tag lets you define different image sources for different screen conditions.

lessons.challenge: Create a responsive image setup that loads different images for mobile and desktop.
tips: Use srcset and sizes for flexible images.
Ensure fallback tag always exists.
Test images on different devices.

lessons.title: Adding Video to Webpages
lessons.content: The <video> tag embeds video files. It supports controls, autoplay, and loop attributes.

examples.code:
<video controls width='400'>
  <source src='video.mp4' type='video/mp4'>
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
examples.description: Embedding a video file in HTML

quiz.question: Which attribute adds play/pause controls to a video?
quiz.hint: It gives user control over playback.
quiz.explanation: The controls attribute displays play, pause, and volume controls for videos.

lessons.challenge: Add a video to your webpage with controls and a fallback message.
tips: Use MP4 format for broad compatibility.
Always include fallback text inside <video>.
Avoid autoplay for user experience.

lessons.title: Embedding Audio
lessons.content: The <audio> tag lets you embed sound files like MP3 or OGG. You can use controls, autoplay, and loop attributes.

examples.code:
<audio controls>
  <source src='music.mp3' type='audio/mpeg'>
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
examples.description: Embedding an audio player

quiz.question: Which HTML tag is used to play sound on a webpage?
quiz.hint: Think of the word 'audio'.
quiz.explanation: The <audio> tag embeds sound content such as music or podcasts.

lessons.challenge: Add background music or a sound clip to your page with play/pause control.
tips: Provide multiple formats (mp3, ogg) for compatibility.
Always give users playback control.
Add fallback text for unsupported browsers.

lessons.title: Embedding External Media (YouTube & iFrames)
lessons.content: You can embed external media like YouTube videos or maps using the <iframe> tag. It allows embedding another page inside your webpage.

examples.description: Embedding a YouTube video using iframe

quiz.question: Which tag allows embedding external content?
quiz.hint: It literally creates an inline frame.
quiz.explanation: The <iframe> tag embeds another webpage or media source inside the current page.

lessons.challenge: Embed a YouTube video and a Google Map on your webpage.
tips: Set width and height for iframes.
Use allowfullscreen for videos.
Avoid using too many iframes to keep pages fast.

lessons.title: Introduction to HTML Forms
lessons.content: HTML forms collect user input and send it to a server. The <form> element wraps input fields, buttons, and other elements. Forms typically use action and method attributes.

examples.description: Basic form structure with input and button

quiz.question: Which tag defines a form in HTML?
quiz.hint: It wraps all input fields together.
quiz.explanation: The <form> element defines a form that can contain multiple inputs and controls for submitting data.

lessons.challenge: Create a basic form with text and password fields and a submit button.
tips: Use method='post' for secure data submission.
Group related fields inside one form element.
Give every input a unique name.

lessons.title: Text Fields and Labels
lessons.content: Labels improve accessibility by describing form fields. The <label> tag links to an input via the for attribute.

examples.description: Using label with input field

quiz.question: How do you associate a label with an input field?
quiz.hint: They should share the same value.
quiz.explanation: The label’s for attribute must match the input’s id for proper association.

lessons.challenge: Create a labeled input form asking for name and email.
tips: Always use labels for accessibility.
Match label 'for' and input 'id'.
Use placeholders for hints, not as labels.

lessons.title: Input Types
lessons.content: HTML supports various input types such as text, email, number, date, and password. These types help browsers provide the right input controls.

examples.code:
<input type='email' placeholder='Enter your email'>
<input type='password' placeholder='Enter password'>
<input type='date'>
examples.description: Examples of different input types

quiz.question: Which input type is used for email addresses?
quiz.hint: It includes built-in validation for email format.
quiz.explanation: The input type='email' ensures users enter valid email addresses.

lessons.challenge: Create a signup form using text, email, and password input types.
tips: Choose the correct input type for better UX.
Browsers validate some types automatically.
Use placeholder to show expected format.

lessons.title: Checkboxes and Radio Buttons
lessons.content: Checkboxes allow multiple selections, while radio buttons let users select only one option in a group.

examples.code:
<label><input type='checkbox' name='skills' value='HTML'> HTML</label>
<label><input type='checkbox' name='skills' value='CSS'> CSS</label>
<label><input type='radio' name='gender' value='male'> Male</label>
<label><input type='radio' name='gender' value='female'> Female</label>
examples.description: Using checkboxes and radio buttons

quiz.question: Which input type allows selecting only one option at a time?
quiz.hint: Used for exclusive choices.
quiz.explanation: Radio buttons with the same name allow only one selection at a time.

lessons.challenge: Create a survey form with checkboxes for skills and radio buttons for gender.
tips: Group related radio buttons with the same name.
Use labels for clarity.
Check boxes can be used independently.

lessons.title: Select Menus and Textareas
lessons.content: Select menus provide dropdown lists. The <textarea> tag is used for multi-line text input.

examples.code:
<select name='country'>
  <option value='pk'>Pakistan</option>
  <option value='in'>India</option>
</select>
<textarea rows='4' cols='30'>Enter your message here...</textarea>
examples.description: Dropdown and textarea example

quiz.question: Which tag creates a dropdown menu?
quiz.hint: It wraps all <option> elements.
quiz.explanation: The <select> element defines a dropdown, with <option> tags inside for choices.

lessons.challenge: Create a feedback form using a dropdown for country and textarea for comments.
tips: Use <option> inside <select> for choices.
Set a default option using 'selected'.
Use textarea for long text input.

lessons.title: Creating Tables
lessons.content: HTML tables organize data into rows and columns using <table>, <tr>, <th>, and <td> tags.

examples.description: Simple table with headers and rows

quiz.question: Which tag defines a table row?
quiz.hint: Used to group table cells horizontally.
quiz.explanation: The <tr> tag defines a single row of table cells.

lessons.challenge: Create a table showing three students with name, age, and grade columns.
tips: Use <th> for headers and <td> for data cells.
Add borders using CSS instead of 'border' attribute.
Tables are best for structured data, not layout.

lessons.title: Table Head, Body, and Footer
lessons.content: Use <thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot> to structure table sections for readability and accessibility.

examples.description: Organized table with head, body, and footer

quiz.question: Which tag defines the main data section of a table?
quiz.hint: It contains the data rows.
quiz.explanation: The <tbody> element holds the primary data content in the table.

lessons.challenge: Build a product list with <thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot>.
tips: Use <thead> for headers and <tfoot> for totals.
Improves accessibility and styling.
Helps screen readers navigate data.

lessons.title: Merging Table Cells
lessons.content: Use colspan and rowspan attributes to merge cells horizontally or vertically.

examples.description: Using colspan to merge cells

quiz.question: Which attribute merges cells horizontally?
quiz.hint: Think 'columns'.
quiz.explanation: colspan merges cells horizontally across columns.

lessons.challenge: Create a timetable merging cells for multi-hour events.
tips: Use colspan for columns and rowspan for rows.
Avoid excessive merging—it can confuse layout.
Keep table data readable.

lessons.title: Introduction to Semantic HTML
lessons.content: Semantic HTML uses meaningful tags like <header>, <footer>, <article>, and <section> to describe content structure.

examples.code:
My Blog

Post Title

Post content here...

© 2025 My Blog
examples.description: Example of semantic HTML layout

quiz.question: Which tag represents a self-contained piece of content?
quiz.hint: Used for blog posts or independent entries.
quiz.explanation: The <article> tag defines a self-contained block of related content.

lessons.challenge: Structure a blog layout using header, article, and footer.
tips: Use semantic tags instead of <div> when possible.
Improves SEO and accessibility.
Browsers and assistive tools recognize semantic meaning.

lessons.title: HTML5 Structural Elements
lessons.content: HTML5 introduced structural tags like <main>, <aside>, <nav>, and <section> to organize layouts clearly.

examples.description: Using structural HTML5 elements

quiz.question: Which tag defines navigation links in HTML5?
quiz.hint: Used for site menus and links.
quiz.explanation: The <nav> element defines navigation links for site structure.

lessons.challenge: Design a webpage using <header>, <nav>, <section>, <aside>, and <footer>.
tips: Use <main> for central content.
Use <aside> for side info or ads.
Keep each section focused on one purpose.

lessons.title: Introduction to Form Validation
lessons.content: HTML5 provides built-in validation attributes to ensure users enter correct data before submitting forms. Common attributes include required, minlength, maxlength, and pattern.

examples.code:
<form>
  <input type='text' name='username' required minlength='3'>
  <input type='email' name='email' required>
  <button type='submit'>Submit</button>
</form>
examples.description: Form using required and minlength validation

quiz.question: Which attribute makes an input field mandatory?
quiz.hint: It ensures the field cannot be left empty.
quiz.explanation: The 'required' attribute forces users to fill the input before submitting the form.

lessons.challenge: Create a registration form that requires username and email validation.
tips: Use built-in attributes before adding JavaScript validation.
Test validation with both valid and invalid inputs.
Keep error messages clear and helpful.

lessons.title: Pattern and Input Restrictions
lessons.content: The pattern attribute defines a regular expression that input data must match. It's useful for formats like phone numbers or passwords.

examples.description: Restrict input to 4 digits using pattern attribute

quiz.question: What does the pattern attribute use to define input rules?
quiz.hint: It checks patterns like email or numbers.
quiz.explanation: Pattern uses regex to match specific text formats.

lessons.challenge: Create a phone number input that only accepts 10 digits.
tips: Always include a 'title' attribute for user guidance.
Use regex carefully—complex patterns can confuse users.
Combine pattern with required for stronger validation.

lessons.title: Custom Validation Messages
lessons.content: Custom validation messages can be displayed using JavaScript’s setCustomValidity() method to give better feedback.

examples.code:
<input id='email' type='email' required>
<script>
const email = document.getElementById('email');
email.oninvalid = () => email.setCustomValidity('Please enter a valid email address.');
email.oninput = () => email.setCustomValidity('');
</script>
examples.description: Setting custom validation messages with JavaScript

quiz.question: Which method is used to set a custom validation message?
quiz.hint: It’s part of the constraint validation API.
quiz.explanation: setCustomValidity() allows you to define your own error message for an input.

lessons.challenge: Add custom messages for invalid email and password inputs.
tips: Use clear and friendly messages.
Clear validation messages when input changes.
Avoid overly technical wording.

lessons.title: ARIA and Accessibility Basics
lessons.content: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes make web apps accessible to users with disabilities. Common attributes: aria-label, aria-hidden, role.

examples.description: Using aria-label and aria-hidden for accessibility

quiz.question: Which ARIA attribute hides content from screen readers?
quiz.hint: It means assistive tech will ignore the element.
quiz.explanation: aria-hidden='true' makes the element invisible to screen readers.

lessons.challenge: Add ARIA labels to buttons and navigation links for accessibility.
tips: Use ARIA only when standard HTML isn't enough.
Avoid overusing aria-hidden.
Always test with screen readers.

lessons.title: Accessible Forms and Labels
lessons.content: Accessible forms help users navigate easily using screen readers. Use <label>, fieldsets, and clear error messages.

examples.description: Accessible form with fieldset and legend

quiz.question: Which tag groups related inputs for accessibility?
quiz.hint: It works together with <legend>.
quiz.explanation: fieldset groups form controls and legend provides a title for that group.

lessons.challenge: Create an accessible survey form using fieldsets and legends.
tips: Always include legends in fieldsets.
Avoid using placeholders as labels.
Provide text alternatives for visual cues.

lessons.title: Embedding Audio in HTML
lessons.content: The <audio> tag is used to play sound files like MP3 or OGG directly in the browser.

examples.code:
<audio controls>
  <source src='sound.mp3' type='audio/mpeg'>
  Your browser does not support the audio tag.
</audio>
examples.description: Embedding an audio file with controls

quiz.question: Which attribute displays playback controls?
quiz.hint: It shows play and pause buttons.
quiz.explanation: The controls attribute makes the browser display audio controls for user interaction.

lessons.challenge: Embed an audio player that automatically plays background music.
tips: Use controls for user accessibility.
Avoid autoplay unless necessary.
Include fallback text for unsupported browsers.

lessons.title: Embedding Video in HTML
lessons.content: The <video> tag plays video files like MP4, OGG, or WebM directly in the browser.

examples.code:
<video width='400' controls>
  <source src='video.mp4' type='video/mp4'>
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
examples.description: Embedding video with controls

quiz.question: Which tag is used to display videos?
quiz.hint: It’s part of HTML5 media features.
quiz.explanation: The <video> element allows embedding video files directly in webpages.

lessons.challenge: Create a video player with autoplay and loop features.
tips: Provide multiple formats for compatibility.
Use controls to improve usability.
Always include fallback text.

lessons.title: Using the Canvas API
lessons.content: The <canvas> tag allows you to draw graphics using JavaScript. It’s often used for games, charts, and animations.

examples.code:
<canvas id='myCanvas' width='200' height='100'></canvas>
<script>
const ctx = document.getElementById('myCanvas').getContext('2d');
ctx.fillStyle = 'blue';
ctx.fillRect(20, 20, 150, 50);
</script>
examples.description: Drawing a blue rectangle with Canvas API

quiz.question: Which method draws a filled rectangle on canvas?
quiz.hint: It fills a rectangular area.
quiz.explanation: The fillRect(x, y, width, height) method fills a rectangle with color.

lessons.challenge: Draw a smiley face using the Canvas API.
tips: Always define canvas width and height attributes.
Use getContext('2d') to access drawing functions.
Clear canvas using clearRect().

lessons.title: HTML5 Local Storage
lessons.content: Local Storage allows web apps to store data in the browser. It uses key-value pairs and persists even after page reloads.

examples.description: Storing and retrieving data in Local Storage

quiz.question: Which method saves data in localStorage?
quiz.hint: It stores data using a key and a value.
quiz.explanation: localStorage.setItem(key, value) stores data that persists after page reload.

lessons.challenge: Create a form that saves username in localStorage and displays it on reload.
tips: Use getItem() to retrieve data.
Use removeItem() to delete a specific key.
Clear all data with clear().

lessons.title: HTML5 Geolocation API
lessons.content: The Geolocation API retrieves the user’s location (latitude and longitude) with permission.

examples.description: Using Geolocation API to get current position

quiz.question: Which object is used to access the user's location?
quiz.hint: It’s a property of the navigator object.
quiz.explanation: navigator.geolocation provides methods to get the user’s current location.

lessons.challenge: Create a button that shows the user’s current latitude and longitude on click.
tips: Always request permission before accessing location.
Handle errors using an error callback.
Never store location data without user consent.

lessons.title: Introduction to Responsive Design
lessons.content: Responsive design ensures web pages look good on all devices by adjusting layout, images, and typography automatically. It’s achieved through flexible grids, images, and CSS media queries.

examples.description: Viewport meta tag for responsive design

quiz.question: Which meta tag is essential for responsive design?
quiz.hint: It controls the page’s scaling on different devices.
quiz.explanation: The viewport meta tag ensures that the page scales properly on mobile and tablet devices.

lessons.challenge: Add a viewport meta tag and create a layout that adjusts on smaller screens.
tips: Always include the viewport meta tag.
Test your layout on mobile and tablet devices.
Use percentages or rem units for flexible design.

lessons.title: Using CSS Media Queries
lessons.content: Media queries let you apply different CSS styles depending on screen size, orientation, or device type. They’re key to responsive layouts.

examples.description: Changing background color for smaller screens

quiz.question: Which CSS rule enables responsive styling based on screen width?
quiz.hint: It checks device properties before applying styles.
quiz.explanation: Media queries begin with @media and let you define conditional CSS rules for specific screen sizes.

lessons.challenge: Create a page that changes font size and color for mobile devices.
tips: Use min-width for mobile-first design.
Group related queries together for readability.
Avoid excessive breakpoints.

lessons.title: Flexible Images and Units
lessons.content: Flexible images scale automatically to fit their containers using CSS properties like max-width: 100%. Relative units like %, em, and rem adapt layouts better.

examples.description: Making images responsive using CSS

quiz.question: Which CSS property ensures images don’t overflow their container?
quiz.hint: It prevents images from exceeding container width.
quiz.explanation: max-width: 100% makes images scale down responsively while maintaining aspect ratio.

lessons.challenge: Make all images on your page resize dynamically with screen width.
tips: Always set height to auto for proportional scaling.
Use SVGs for better scalability.
Avoid fixed-width images in responsive layouts.

lessons.title: Responsive Navigation Menus
lessons.content: Responsive navigation menus adapt to different screen sizes using toggles, icons, or dropdowns for mobile views.

examples.description: Basic responsive navigation list

quiz.question: What’s a common design for mobile menus?
quiz.hint: It’s a 3-line icon representing menu options.
quiz.explanation: A hamburger menu collapses navigation links into an icon for small screens.

lessons.challenge: Create a navigation bar that collapses into a hamburger icon on mobile.
tips: Use CSS transitions for smooth animations.
Keep menus short and clear.
